Part: 1.1 Real Numbers and The Number Line
Description/Solution: The distance between 0 and the real number a on the number line, denoted |a|. Because the absolute value is defined to be a distance, it will always be positive. It is worth noting that |0| = 0.

Description/Solution:
When first learning how to subtract real numbers, it is useful to think of this operation as adding opposite numbers.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-P7_Qp9AjjtU/UJH199BHXnI/AAAAAAAACeI/9eJLk1klSjA/s1600/ex01-0101.PNG

Two sequential negative signs, as seen above, is equivalent to addition. When adding two negative numbers the result will be negative.

Name/Problem: Two sequential negative signs is equivalent to _.
Multiplying (or dividing) a negative number by a positive number will result in a _ number.
Multiplying (or dividing) two negative numbers the result will be _.

Description/Solution:
(or "rational number"); a real number that can be written as a quotient, or ratio, of two integers

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-L3X4ErmHT9I/UJKfxQK7xVI/AAAAAAAAChg/wmenG3NubnU/s1600/ex01-0401.PNG

Name/Problem: reduce fractions to lowest terms (cancel common factors)
Description/Solution:
Fractions in lowest terms have no common factors in the numerator and denominator other than 1.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-YK_3Z73pzPM/UJKf7k5iljI/AAAAAAAAChw/mSDDco9hBKA/s1600/ex01-0403.PNG

Identify the greatest common factor (GCF) of the numerator and denominator and then divide both by that number.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mCXVpsEh63Q/UJKgAiRad8I/AAAAAAAACh4/YDwSaWZliYg/s1600/ex01-0404.PNG
a fraction where the numerator is larger than the denominator

Name/Problem: convert an improper fraction to a mixed number
Description/Solution:
To convert an improper fraction to a mixed number, simply divide. The quotient is the whole number part and the remainder is the new numerator.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iIBaEf-2gJ8/UJKgHZUSJ8I/AAAAAAAACiA/uVA8x23oJrA/s1600/ex01-0407b.PNG

To multiply fractions, you multiply the numerators and the denominators. NO COMMON DENOMINATOR is required.

When multiplying, look for factors to cancel before actually multiplying the numerators and denominators.  This will eliminate the need to reduce the end result.

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-CTphtdTWTAU/UJKgx5aKO_I/AAAAAAAACi4/P1u-mtOYR6E/s1600/ex01-0411.PNG

To divide fractions, you multiply the numerator by the reciprocal of the divisor.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-QbCJCdCd7yI/UJKg3FvRSdI/AAAAAAAACjA/NQaurSmTCJw/s1600/ex01-0412.PNG

Name/Problem: convert mixed numbers to improper fractions
Description/Solution:
Convert mixed numbers to improper fractions before you multiply or divide. To do this, multiply the denominator with the whole number then add the numerator, this will be the new numerator.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-yy7azksJRvI/UJKiSm7CZ-I/AAAAAAAACkQ/kFAwnm-bzUM/s1600/ex01-0422.PNG

You will have to find the equivalent fractions with a common denominator before you can add or subtract them.

Step 1: Determine the least common multiple of the denominators (LCD).
Step 2: Multiply numerator and denominator by what you need to obtain equivalent fractions with that LCD.
Step 3: Add the numerators and write the result over the common denominator.
Step 4: Reduce if necessary.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-nNh3r261e4Q/UJKjxvIz1jI/AAAAAAAAClg/b1_MNJPZxes/s1600/ex01-0432.PNG

If fractions have a common denominator, simply add or subtract the values found in the numerator and write the result over the common denominator and reduce if necessary.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-WCcHtH36IUE/UJKi7LNkO3I/AAAAAAAACk4/eHJ8Wgbosnw/s1600/ex01-0427.PNG

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-a-etRQWRb8U/UJKjAfe8D_I/AAAAAAAAClA/8LRGNalZRH8/s1600/ex01-0428.PNG

Name/Problem: A board that is 5 1/4 feet long is cut into 7 pieces of equal length. What is the length of each piece?
A muffin recipe calls for 1 2/3 cups of flour to make 4 muffins.  How many cups of flower does the recipe require if you wish to make 16 muffins?

Description/Solution:
Write the number over 100 and eliminate the percent symbol %, then reduce if necessary.

http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-t55dbFImVd0/UJLYrrQXo_I/AAAAAAAACng/OwUGDCRigUQ/s1600/ex01-0502.PNG

To find a decimal equivalent divide.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-8hMv3fjKBII/UJLY4Lgxz9I/AAAAAAAACno/wf5ncP5BoGg/s1600/ex01-0503.PNG

Moving the decimal over 2 places to the left.

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-VFRZM1LbgTI/UJLY-7AeAnI/AAAAAAAACnw/wMnokxyGKcE/s1600/ex01-0504.PNG

This works because a percent is part of 100 and dividing by 100 simply moves the decimal two places.

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jPHqAniJo5o/UJLZMIC-mWI/AAAAAAAACn4/ZL9Xtmij6ek/s1600/ex01-0505a.PNG

Name/Problem: write a decimal as a percent
Description/Solution:
To write a decimal as a percent, you can multiply by 1 = 100%. For example,

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-jTRQZbPErQ4/UJMiHvhi7nI/AAAAAAAACpk/IToxKA5n7kE/s1600/ex01-0516b.PNG
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-DaR7AXe-huM/UJMiO6RKL8I/AAAAAAAACps/WrPXd1SAeDU/s1600/ex01-0516a.PNG

This can be done quickly by moving the decimal to the right two places.  One way to remember how to convert between decimals and percents is to use the letters D and P in alphabetical order and the following illustration.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-wwxcCZ0i29E/UJMidlZ_A5I/AAAAAAAACp0/1KXY134taWU/s1600/ex01-0515.PNG

If you have a decimal the illustration shows to move the decimal two places to the right. If you have a percent the illustration shows to move the decimal two places to the left.

Name/Problem: converting percents to fractions and reduce
Description/Solution:
Converting percents to fractions there really is no easy trick.  The idea is to use the definition and then reduce.  You must remember that a percent is a part of 100.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-PheM16Sav1w/UJMjiKEMo7I/AAAAAAAACrE/-eKziFq7Pqo/s1600/ex01-0531.PNG

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-xv0NhsKF_zs/UJMjnTaE4FI/AAAAAAAACrM/ZwI2H-Jr6AA/s1600/ex01-0532.PNG

Name/Problem: A calculator is advertised at $12.99 plus a 7.5% sales tax.  What is the total including tax?
After a nice dinner out, the bill came to $35.75.  For good service you wish to leave a 15% tip.  What is the total including the tip?

Description/Solution:
To square a number means to multiply that number times itself.  For example:

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-hzTZTLSSddI/UJMoeoDQ0jI/AAAAAAAACs4/XOdwGRnNa2E/s1600/ex01-0601.PNG

The number 5 is called the base and the integer 2 is called the exponent. Another way to read the above example is "5 raised to the second power."

The square root can be thought of as the opposite of squaring a number.  In other words, if we want the square root of 16 the question is "what number squared gives 16?"  Actually there are two answers to this question, 4 and −4 because:

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-e3GQoGPehxY/UJMpGWcMy0I/AAAAAAAACtw/QIMBrMFpHHA/s1600/ex01-0608.PNG

Hence, there is a technical distinction here. When we are asked for the square root of numbers we mean the principal (non-negative) square root.

If A and B are positive and real the following property is useful for simplifying square roots:

http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-YO9Hyq92dAU/UJMpwLp2GaI/AAAAAAAACuo/DsYpFx5O0Xo/s1600/ex01-0615.PNG

Look for the largest perfect square factor and the apply this property as follows:

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iQewX0ErKtY/UJMp2pSx9oI/AAAAAAAACuw/ymDEYlt9lSo/s1600/ex01-0615a.PNG

When several operations are to be applied within a calculation, we must follow a specific order to ensure a single correct result.

Order of Operations:
- Perform all calculations within the innermost Parentheses first.
- Evaluate Exponent expressions.
- Apply the Multiplication and Division operations from left to right.
- Lastly, work all Addition and Subtraction operations from left to right.

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-LtnwzWh7qC0/UJPcOAGkn4I/AAAAAAAACvg/bkX19UeQ5ac/s1600/ex01-0701.PNG

Order of operation problems get a bit more tedious when fractions are involved. Remember that when adding or subtracting fractions you need to first find the equivalent fractions with a common denominator. Multiplication does not require a common denominator.

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0HJybMNKwOY/UJPeh7jgIHI/AAAAAAAACxY/DRGkKEQUfQw/s1600/ex01-0715.PNG

http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-aKB5CYbFwm0/UJPelsAQrgI/AAAAAAAACxg/a0j7Sm1uySE/s1600/ex01-0716.PNG

Name/Problem: order of operations with absolute values
Description/Solution:
Some problems may involve an absolute value, in which case you will need to apply the innermost absolute value first as you would if it were a parentheses.

http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Pi2ihihsDpc/UJPgfU08ddI/AAAAAAAACy4/NgFVuPaebWo/s1600/ex01-0727.PNG
